==Descriptions==
{{Description|In the ancient literary canon of Sumeru, "Chinvat" represents the bitter sea of ignorance that those who seek wisdom must cross to see the light of the truth on the other shore.<br />These days, those who navigate the forests use this term to describe the ravine under the [[Divine Tree]], perhaps in honor of the elation they feel upon finally reaching the city of wisdom.|[[Expedition]] description}}

==Trivia==
===Etymology===
* {{Lang|{{w|Chinvat Bridge}}|ae=𐬗𐬌𐬥𐬬𐬀𐬙𐬋 𐬞𐬈𐬭𐬈𐬙𐬏𐬨|ae_rm=Cinvatô Peretûma|ae_tl=bridge of judgement}} is a sifting bridge in Zoroastrianism which separates the world of the living from the world of the dead.
* In the Chinese name of Chinvat Ravine, {{Lang|''Lídù''|zh=离渡|zh_tl=Separate and cross}} is derived form {{Lang|''Lídù zhī Qiáo''|zh=离渡之桥|zh_tl=Separating-and-Crossing Bridge|zh_rm=}}, a translation of {{w|Chinvat Bridge}}.
